review.title: CRF-based Named Entity Recognition @ICON 2013
review.abstract: This paper describes performance of CRF based systems for Named Entity Recognition (NER) in Indian language as a part of ICON 2013 shared task. In this task we have considered a set of language independent features for all the languages. Only for English a language specific feature, i.e. capitalization, has been added. Next the use of gazetteer is explored for Bengali, Hindi and English. The gazetteers are built from Wikipedia and other sources. Test results show that the system achieves the highest F measure of 88% for English and the lowest F measure of 69% for both Tamil and Telugu. Note that for the least performing two languages no gazetteer was used. NER in Bengali and Hindi finds accuracy (F measure) of 87% and 79%, respectively.

metadata.title: CRF-based Named Entity Recognition @ICON 2013

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In the field of NLP (Natural Language Processing) and IR (Information Retrieval), most Indian languages play a crucial role due to some inherent problems. For example, there are some designated entities, each of which has a valid dictionary entry. Unlike English, developing an NER system for most Indian languages is difficult because there is no capitalization information, no free-speech structure, and no inflexibility in many Indian languages. In addition, gazetteers play an important role in the development of a practical NERS system. But building well-diversified gazetteers requires hard and time-consuming work. Therefore, developing a practical NERS system is still an active and challenging area of research. Although there is some research to develop a NERS system for Indian languages, further research is needed to develop a better understanding of the problem and thus create a workable system.

sections.heading: 2 Training and Test Data
sections.text: ICON has provided us with training, development and test data (8: 1: 1 ratio) for the joint task in the Indian languages Hindi, Bengali, Punjabi, Telugu, Urdu and English. Details of the data set are given in Table 1.

sections.heading: 3 CRF-based NE's Detection
sections.text: We used the Conditional Random Field (CRF's) [Lafferty et al., 2001] to predict the class alive in the Named Entity Recognition task. In our experiment, we used the CRF + + 1, an open source package. We used various combinations of language-independent features [Ekbal et al., 2008] and finally selected the features for which we obtained the highest precision on a development set. Below, the details of the features used in the NE recognition task: • Context Words: The previous and next word of a particular word. • Word Prefix and Suffix: We took into account the word prefix and suffix from 3 letter lengths to 5 letter lengths for all NNNPs. • POS and Chunk Information: We used the POS and chunk information of a particular word as a feature. • First and Last Words: We used the first word of a sentence and the last word of a sentence, i.e. the last word of a sentence (n).

sections.heading: 4 Results and Error Analysis
sections.text: The result of the joint task of ICON and 2013 is in Table 2. From the results we can conclude that gazettes are very helpful in increasing the performance of a NERs. Since we have used gazettes in Bengali, Hindi and English, their preformities in relation to Tamil and Telegu, for which we have not used gazettes, seem to be much better.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: The goal of this experiment was the rapid development of NER for Indian languages. It is well known that the CRF-based approach can achieve this goal with limited accuracy. It is well known that the role of the gazetteer is as important for Indian languages as it is for English. It is true that building a diversified gazetteer is time consuming and tedious, but some tricks such as using wiki names, telephone e-directories, who's who lists, etc., can help to create gazetteers without much manual intervention. We have practiced this aspect in the present experiment and were able to improve the performance of the system. However, more language processing may be needed to capture an essentially valid dictionary.

sections.text: We would like to thank the organizers of the ICON2013 NER Tool Competition.
